Particle motion under an applied electric field is known as electrophoresis. The sample particles are suspended in a solvent at known refractive index n, velocity η and dielectric constant ε. The sample is irradiated with laser light of wavelength λ [ 53]. An electric field with strength E is applied. Due to the electric field, the particles are moving. Because the particles are moving, the scattered light at angle ϑ is measured, and the particle velocity V is determined from the frequency shift. Mobility is then readily obtained as the ratio of velocity to the electric field strength V/E. Zeta potential is found using the most common model known as the Smulochowski model.
